p.s: Sonnet 116, written by William Shakespeare in the 16th century, is positioned in the sequence of the young man.
It follows, that the idea of the sonnet is related to the love of the speaker to this young man.
The main aspect of the sonnet is the comparison of love to landmark or star.
Therefore love is limitless, strong and stable, not easy to break.
In the first quatrain (cf. v. 1-4) the speaker directly starts with defining what love doesn't mean to him.

Therefore love isn't a connection based on obstacles and only with compromises nor it is short timed, because somebody has found another love and changed his mind, due to his active search for somebody new.
This would mean, that at least onepart of the relationship is unhappy about the connection.
In contrast to that, the speaker points out what real and emotionally deep love actually is (cf. v. 5-8).
In the second quatrain, the speaker compairscompares a landmark or star with this love (his idea of love).
Therefore this star has the overview over every storm and doesn't get effected by the storms as well as that the star guides lost boats.
But nobody knows the values of the landmark and just the distance between them.
In the third quatrain (cf. v. 9-12), love gets described by what it doesn't mean and shouldn't be, too: Love shouldn't be dependenddependent on time and limited ontime.
But on the other side the only thing that can stop the love is death.
So it follows, that love must exists till death and not only for a few weeks.

In the closing couplet (cf. vv. 13f.) the speaker sums his idea of love up and makes a conclusion: This idea of an unlimited and strong, stabilestable love exists, because he writes love poems and other men love, too.
